id: 2025 Peter Turner Lecture in Photography - Anne Noble-55 Cable Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
name: 2025 Peter Turner Lecture in Photography - Anne Noble
description:
Photography – The Art of Paying Attention
In this lecture Anne Noble will discuss modes of collaborative practice across a series of projects that spans her work with bees as well as current projects concerning the environmental degradation of our waterways. In 2023 Anne Noble was commissioned by Ngāi Tahu to create an archive of images that would reveal the deteriorating state of freshwater across South Island waterways and the resulting impact on mahinga kai customs and practices. These photographs supported the Ngāi Tahu Statement of Claim heard recently in the High Court in Ōtautahi Christchurch, seeking recognition of Rangatiratanga (authority) over wai māori (fresh water) within Ngāi Tahu takiwā. An exhibition, drawing on the archive and created collaboratively is currently showing in Ōtepoti, at the Dunedin Public Art Gallery.
Free entry, however bookings are advised. Doors open at 6.15pm, Lecture at 6.30pm. Lecture will finish at 8pm, please join us for refreshments afterwards.
Anne Noble has been at the forefront of photographic practice in New Zealand since the early 1980s, creating bodies of work that mark sustained engagement with particular places, sites, histories, species and more recently the environmental degradation of land and water. Her images are known for their beauty, complexity and conceptual rigour and for their persistent inquiry into the ways photography impacts our perception, understanding and relationship to the natural world. Anne Noble is Professor Emerita of Fine Arts (Photography) at Massey University, Wellington and is the recipient of numerous awards including the 31st Higashikawa Photography Award (2015), an Arts Foundation Laureate Award (2009) and US National Science Foundation Artists and Writers Award (2008). She has exhibited widely both nationally and internationally and her work is held in collections throughout the world.
This year's lecture is one of a number of events celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Photography programme at Te Kunenga ki Pūrehuroa Massey University.
The Peter Turner Memorial Lecture was established in 2008, in the memory of the late Peter Turner historian, curator and former editor of Creative Camera magazine who came from the UK to live in NZ in 1981. His contributions to the medium of photography during his time in New Zealand spanned curatorial work, writing, reviewing and teaching. He is remembered for his passion for the medium, support of photographers and their work and his special love of practices he termed lyric, transcendent or poetic documentary photography. Founded on reflections on this legacy the annual Peter Turner Lecture is conceived as a means to broaden discussions about the social and cultural value of the medium of photography today – as an expanded field inclusive of a broad range of lens based media and approaches.
In association with the Peter Turner Lecture a fund has been established by the Massey University Foundation to support the Peter Turner Scholarship that was launched in association with the lecture and each year provides a postgraduate student scholarship for a student engaging with social and cultural issues through the medium of photography in its broadest sense.
The Peter Turner Fund has been established by the Massey University Foundation to grow the support this scholarship can offer young photographers aspiring for a career the lens based arts.

id: ACT for Everybody, July 2025-21 Hania Street Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: ACT for Everybody, July 2025
description:
Life can be hard.
We want to help you manage life when it’s difficult. And we know that for many people ACT has a profound and positive effect on wellbeing.
ACT for Everybody is a 6 week course where you’ll learn how to interact more helpfully with thoughts, feelings and behaviours that you struggle with. You’ll develop your ability to move towards what matters to you even when you’re feeling bad. And you’ll do this with a small group of others.
We know that people wonder whether groups are for them! We find that discovering ACT in a group provides special opportunities to learn from each other and highlight how all our minds get stuck in struggle at times. The course includes chances to share but you can choose how much or little you contribute. Here is some feedback from a previous participant:
The course gave me scheduled time to stop and reflect in a non-threatening environment. It wasn’t rushed, it wasn’t pressured but there was a lot of skills, knowledge and tools that through the course became part of me. The course opened up struggles within me that I did not know were there and helped me deal with them. It gave me tools to deal with feelings that sent me in a spiral to dark places. It taught me that I can always do something. I went to the course believing that I was not brave enough to live my life and left with the courage to live it.
What is ACT?
We think about Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) as a way of helping people live their lives based on their values, and without painful thoughts and feelings getting in the way.
Emotional pain is a normal and unavoidable part of human experience. Often it is the struggle to avoid painful thoughts and feelings that leads to suffering. ACT is literally about taking action: accepting what you can’t change and committing to what you can.
What can I expect?
ACT for Everybody is a supportive, interesting, safe, confidential and fun course. It’s facilitated by experienced psychologists with between 8 and 14 participants. It runs for 2 hours on Tuesday afternoons, from 4:00pm to 6:00pm.
You need to join us for the first night of the course in order to take part in the rest of the course.


Giselle Bahr is a clinical psychologist and co-founder of ACT Wellington. She has been using ACT in her practice for over 15 years, and has been trained and supervised by many of the world’s leading ACT therapists and researchers. Giselle has worked at Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services, in Private Practice with adults and adolescents, and trained new clinical psychology students at Victoria University of Wellington. Giselle has developed and facilitates a group introducing ACT to Parents.
Tania Stanton works as a clinical psychologist at the Maternal Mental Health Service. She has previously worked in Infant, Child, Adolescent and Family Services where she co-developed and facilitated therapy groups for young people and their parents using ACT. She is enthusiastic about the help that ACT can offer to enhance people's lives.

id: After Austen: Em-57 Willis Street  Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: After Austen: Em
description:
We are so excited to welcome award-winning playwright Sam Brooks, to discuss his play Em, a queer retelling of Jane Austen’s masterwork Emma, turned around, flipped and set in our very own Queenstown.
Emmett Woodhouse, handsome, clever and rich, with a comfortable home and a gay disposition has lived nearly [redacted] years in the world with very little to distress or vex him.

Until now.
Em won the Dean Parker Adaptation Award at the 2023 Adam New Zealand Play Awards.

Attendees get an exclusive 10% discount at Unity Books

Sam Brooks is an award-winning and prolific playwright and journalist, who is largely noted for his critically acclaimed LGBTQ+ work, including Riding in Cars with (Mostly Straight) Boys, Queen, and most recently This is My Story of Us, which was co-winner of the 2024 Adam New Zealand Play Award. He won the Bruce Mason Playwright's Award, New Zealand's most prestigious award for playwrights. In 2018 his political work, Burn Her, was performed as part of Q's Matchbox Season and won the Auckland Theatre Excellence Award for Best Overall Production. He has been shortlisted multiple years for the Adam New Zealand Play Award, and won the Dean Parker award in 2023.
As a journalist, he has written for The Spinoff and has had bylines at the Pantrograph Punch, Metro and the NZ Herald.


Afternoon tea provided

id: BEYOND THE BUILD - Wellington-4 Taranaki Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
name: BEYOND THE BUILD - Wellington
description:
UNCOVERING THE HIDDEN RISKS IN CONSTRUCTION & INSURANCE

Get to grips with construction realities - how rebuild values are calculated, why underinsurance is widespread, and what recent compliance changes mean for you and your clients.
Hear from bold, straight-talking experts
Earn two structured CPD points
Network with peers over drinks and canapés

This interactive series will tour five cities - Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington, Hamilton, and Auckland - offering a unique blend of real-world insights, expert panels, and invaluable networking opportunities.
Spaces are limited. Reserve your spot today.‍
WHAT TO EXPECT
Expect a fast-paced, engaging experience designed to give insurance professionals a clear, practical understanding of construction and how it directly impacts risk, rebuild costs, and client conversations.

“It wasn’t until the claim that we realised just how exposed we really were”: From shock at their rebuild shortfall to the challenge of dealing with their loss adjuster and insurer, this real-life account highlights the true impact of underinsurance - and what every insurance professional should take from it.
Localised Expert Panels: Engage with regional brokers and insurers as they unpack both local and national issues shaping the insurance landscape. Expect honest conversations, practical insights, and the chance to ask your own questions.
Construction Market Insights: Get up-to-date perspectives on construction trends, cost drivers, inflation pressures, and emerging opportunities - so you can better understand the forces shaping construction today.
Industry Guest Speaker: Hear directly from an experienced builder who’s worked on the front lines of insurance projects - navigating the complexities of working with insurers, loss adjusters, and property owners during claims.
Insurer Perspective on Underinsurance: Hear directly from one of New Zealand’s leading insurance companies as they share real-world insights into how underinsurance impacts customers—and what it means for brokers and advisers on the front line.
Networking Opportunities: Enjoy complimentary coffee and refreshments throughout the event, then stick around for drinks and food afterwards - an ideal chance to connect with peers, share insights, and build new relationships.

id: Black Flock presents Weird Horror Film Festival-Rintoul Street Wellington, Wellington 6021-Event Brite
name: Black Flock presents Weird Horror Film Festival
description:
Welcome to the first annual Horror Film Festival. Bought to you by Black Flock art collective.
The nights are becoming longer, the wind is howling, the black mold is growing, and the world is a pretty scary place.
Why would we want to do this when the world is aleady a scary place?
Watching horror films for many can be a safe way to process fears, dark fantasies and morbid thoughts. Creativity gives us the means to process and express what goes on inside our minds.Community gives us a place to support each other through scary times, and make our own fun!!!
so.....
Get ready for a Sunday Horror evening where the audience support each others15 minutes of... screaming at the top of their lungs until their (fake) eyeballs pop out, or cross your legs and wince as other inventive special effects and use of prosthetics send quivers through your body. Marvel at the kiwi-ingenuity of your mates improvised sets and costumes. Be astounded as you learn that your flatmate has a dark side and is quite skilled with suspense...whatever genre of horror you go for, be it splatter, psychological, slasher, body horror, these are all short films made within a short time frame, and we expect and encourage B-Z grade styles done on the cheap. We will get through this together comrades!
We will have an awards ceremony on the night with various prize categories, including audiences pick.
Be a part of the fun, grab whatever moving picture recording device you can find, and make a horror film to enter.
Registrations for entering a film for this years screening are now closed (as of May 18th)

The Deadline for submitting your final cut in order to be shown is July 20th.

Come join us for a bloody good time at the Newtown Community Centre - Te Whare Hapori o Nga Puna Waiora Sunday, August 3rd!

id: Courageous Communication™ | 1-day Workshop | Wellington | 23 July 2025-55 Cable Street Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: Courageous Communication™ | 1-day Workshop | Wellington | 23 July 2025
description:
Has this ever happened to you?
You’re sitting in a meeting and there are 50 elephants in the room with you that nobody is mentioning, and you’re doing the strategic plan but everyone knows it’s never going to work because the team don’t have the capability or the capacity and that one person never follows through and that other person thinks her work is better than it is, but nobody says anything and as you leave you think well THAT'S three hours I’m never gonna get back…
It’s hard to say the hard thing.
But saying the hard thing is the only way we can deal with what’s actually going on.
The number one indicator of a lack of courage is an inability to have hard conversations.
Hard conversations are scary. Our hearts start pounding, our tummies clench, our mouths go dry.
Hard conversations feel dangerous. If I say this thing, he’ll be offended! She’ll be angry! I’ll get in trouble!
Hard conversations are tempting to avoid. Nobody else is mentioning these elephants. Why should I?
But what if you were great at them?
What would it mean for your relationships?
What would it mean for your career?
What would it mean for your life?
Kaila Colbin has worked with more than 4,000 people to grow courage as a core competency and a clear framework has emerged from that experience.
In this 1-day workshop, you’ll build the skill and muscle to get great at having hard conversations.
We’ll cover the specific elements of how to communicate and what to communicate.

When: Wednesday, 23 July 2025, 9 am-4:30 pm
Where: Rangimarie Room, Te Papa Museum, 55 Cable Street, Wellington 6011
Lunch, afternoon tea and all-day tea and coffee are included in the registration.

Need help with the cost?
If you are an Educator or at a Not-for-Profit, you can automatically access a special rate of $745 + GST when you register (a $250 discount off our standard General Admission rates).

Our Health and Safety Plan
Boma is committed to delivering safe events. We follow best practices suggested by the New Zealand health authorities and work closely with our suppliers to prioritise health and wellbeing.
Our comprehensive health and safety plans ensure you can book with certainty and attend with confidence.

Our refund policy
For details on event refunds and transfers, please see our refund policy.

About the Kaila Colbin
Kaila Colbin is founder and CEO of Boma, an organisation building a world of intentional, intelligent, courageous leaders.
An award-winning leader renowned for impact, Kaila developed TEDxChristchurch into New Zealand’s flagship TEDx event and brought Singularity University to New Zealand and Australia, supporting thousands of people to engage with exponentially accelerating technologies and their impact on humanity. She trained with Dr Brené Brown as a Certified Dare to Lead™ Facilitator.
As a founder of the non-profit Ministry of Awesome, Kaila played a critical role in developing Christchurch’s startup ecosystem. She has extensive governance experience, and has been involved with mergers, capital raises, and company sales in the US and NZ.
A native New Yorker, Kaila’s work to champion Aotearoa New Zealand on a global stage saw her given the 2022 Kea World Class New Zealand “Friend of New Zealand” award. Her purpose in life is to be an uplifting presence.

If you have any questions about this event, please email us at hello@boma.global.

id: Cultivating a Positive Workplace Culture for High-Performance Teams-157 Lambton Quay #Level 13 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: Cultivating a Positive Workplace Culture for High-Performance Teams
description:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and organisational change agents who want to foster a positive workplace culture that drives high performance, collaboration, and employee wellbeing. Participants will explore the essential principles of creating an environment that nurtures trust, accountability, inclusivity, and engagement. Through practical strategies, case studies, and interactive discussions, participants will learn how to develop a culture that motivates teams to excel, encourages open communication, and supports professional growth.

Key Topics Include:
• Building a culture of trust and psychological safety
• Fostering open communication and feedback loops
• Aligning values and purpose with organisational goals
• Promoting inclusivity, diversity, and belonging
• Recognising and celebrating achievements
• Encouraging work-life balance and wellbeing
• Developing strategies for conflict resolution and collaboration
By the end of the course, participants will have the tools and insights needed to create a workplace environment that not only supports but accelerates the success of high-performing teams, driving both individual and collective achievement.

Key audience:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and anyone responsible for shaping the culture within their teams and organisations.

Learning outcomes:
Implement strategies to cultivate trust, psychological safety, and high performance within their teams.
Lead teams that foster open communication, collaboration, and inclusivity.
Align team goals with organisational values and objectives, ensuring a shared sense of purpose.
Develop effective strategies for conflict resolution and team cohesion.
Create a workplace culture that encourages growth, well-being, and work-life balance.

id: Discover Nonviolent Communication: Expressing Our Needs-175 Vivian Street #Level 1 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: Discover Nonviolent Communication: Expressing Our Needs
description:
Discover Nonviolent Communication: Expressing Our Needs
In this introduction to Nonviolent Communication (NVC), we will focus on recognising feelings and needs (our own and others) in order to communicate with more compassion and clarity.
Plus there is an amazing plant-based dinner & dessert included in your ticket!
NVC is a communication framework that offers connection, transparency and understanding. You will get to know some foundational tools of NVC, and practice on examples from real life. This session is interactive, and you will walk away with some understanding of NVC processes and materials to practice in your own time.
You will learn:
what is NVC (Nonviolent Communication)
what are needs and what role they play in communication and life
how feelings are linked with needs
the difference between needs and strategies (and why it matters)
how to listen beyond words and behaviours (your own and others)
Event followed by a plant-based dinner and dessert, all included in your ticket!

id: Echoes of a Decade - 10th Anniversary Fundraising Concert-53 Hobson Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
name: Echoes of a Decade - 10th Anniversary Fundraising Concert
description:
🎶 Relaxed Fundraising Concert Overview
SoundsWell Singers is a unique and inspiring neurological choir made up of people living with conditions such as Parkinson’s Disease, Huntington’s Disease, Aphasia (post-stroke), and early Dementia. Co-led by two NZ Registered Music Therapists with support from a Speech Language Therapist, the choir has a dual therapeutic focus—promoting both physical and emotional well-being through the joy of singing.
The group meets weekly in a warm, supportive, and social environment. No prior choir or singing experience is needed, and support people are always welcome.
At this special 10th anniversary concert, the choir will perform a mix of well-known songs, and many with their own unique spin.
Come along, show your support, and feel the transformative power of music and community.
🌟 Special Guest: Sophia Gittings
An exciting rising star in the opera world, Sophia is soon heading overseas to further her career. Don't miss this chance to hear her live!
🎟️ Raffle & Silent Auction
Take part in our fundraising raffle and silent auction. Every dollar raised goes directly toward supporting this life-changing choir.
♿ Accessibility
Our concert venue is fully accessible. If you require accessible parking or have any specific needs, please don’t hesitate to contact us; we’ll do our best to accommodate you.
💬 Voices Beyond the Music
Throughout the concert, choir members will share personal stories about their journeys with neurological conditions and how singing has impacted their lives. These heartfelt moments bring deeper meaning to the music and highlight the strength of this incredible community.
❤️ Why It Matters
For many members, it’s a rare opportunity to connect, express themselves, and find joy despite the daily challenges of Aphasia, Parkinson’s, Dementia, and other neurological conditions. Your support helps keep this essential programme running and growing.
🎤 Empower Voices, Change Lives
Join us for an unforgettable evening of song, courage, and community. Bring a friend, bid in the silent auction, grab a raffle ticket, and help us raise funds to ensure this choir continues to change lives—one voice at a time.

id: From Galileo to Laudato Si’: Why Science Needs Faith - Br. Guy Consolmagno-33 Bunny Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
name: From Galileo to Laudato Si’: Why Science Needs Faith - Br. Guy Consolmagno
description:
This event is also available online on Zoom.
How we understand faith and science has changed radically from the time of Galileo, as can be seen in how Pope Francis blended science and faith in his encyclical Laudato Si’. Its key insight is that our science, and the technology it spawns, is deeply connected to the flawed but redeemable human persons who do the science, and who make and live with technology... and its consequences
Br. Guy Consolmagno, SJ, is an American Jesuit brother and planetary scientist, currently serving as the Director of the Vatican Observatory and President of the Vatican Observatory Foundation. He is known for his research on meteorites, asteroids, and the evolution of small solar system bodies, as well as his popular writings on astronomy and faith. He holds degrees from MIT (SB, SM) and the University of Arizona (PhD in Planetary Science) and has worked in astronomy at Harvard and MIT before entering the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) in 1989.
Br. Guy has been at the Vatican Observatory since 1993, curating the meteorite collection and conducting research. He was appointed director in September 2015 by Pope Francis. His research focuses on the physical properties of meteorites and asteroids, including their spectra and how they relate to the evolution of the solar system. He is the author of several popular books, including "Turn Left at Orion" (with Dan Davis) and "Would You Baptize an Extraterrestrial?" (with Paul Mueller, SJ). He is also a popular speaker on the topic of faith and science, and serves on the governing boards of various international scientific organizations.
This event is co-hosted by Te Kupenga – the Catholic Leadership Institute, Te Herenga Waka - Victoria University of Wellington and the Wellington Astronomical Society

id: Hands-on Sourdough Workshop-Headquarters Wakefield, Tasman 7025-Event Brite
name: Hands-on Sourdough Workshop
description:
Sourdough for Beginners - $120 (paid via internet banking)
Come join us for a hands-on, in-person sourdough workshop at Willow Corner Collective headquarters (aka my home)! This workshop is currently the only hands-on sourdough workshop being offered in the Nelson region - I teach and demonstrate to you and then you get to mix and practice on your own dough as we go along.
Whether you're a seasoned baker or a beginner, this event is perfect for anyone looking to master the art of making sourdough bread, learning from someone who has 10+ years of experience. Perhaps you've found all the Youtube tutorials and Instagram how-to's overwhelming and are keen to learn via an in-person class. Then this is for you! I've baked hundreds of loaves in the last year alone, sold at a market, and hosted a pop-up shop. However, my passion really lies with teaching others to bake their own sourdough in their own homes, for their own families (or small businesses - one day!).You will be taught, demonstrated to, and then you get to have a go yourself; whilst learning my tips and tricks along the way. Plus we finish by sampling some delicious, fresh artisan sourdough with some favourite toppings!
You'll go home with all you need to make a good loaf of sourdough bread:
Knowledge
Student Guide, including recipes
Bowl, liner, bowl scraper, and razor blade... all the tools you'd need to make sourdough
Dough made in class to bake the next day at home, to wow your family/friends
Confidence to continue the process yourself
Healthy, bubbling starter to continue your journey at home
Continued support and encouragement via our own private Facebook community group, for class attendees only*I recommend you already have a pair of digital scales, and a cast iron dutch oven at home to bake your loaf with as this makes the best, artisan sourdough, with great rise. Alternatively, a large, lidded casserole dish or enamel roasting pan work also. (The lids are a necessity).
Note: You will have your dough to take home after the workshop that will need shaping around 7pm, so please ensure that will work for you that day.Also, please double check the date when booking. Unfortunately if for some reason you are unable to attend on the day, due to time constraints, I am unable to refund your ticket. I am happy for you to send someone in your place, though. In extenuating circumstances I may be able to hold your ticket for a future workshop; this is decided on a case-by-case basis.
"Sarah’s sour dough class is for real life! Achieve beautiful delicious bread easily in your own kitchen. Sarah teaches you how to fit sourdough into your busy life. She clearly and passionately gives the essential information, tips and tricks to make your own loaf. I loved getting to have a go at each step in the process. I love Sarah’s catchy philosophy “The goal is good bread, not perfect bread.” This took all the pressure off, for me, and I left the class empowered with all the knowledge and skills needed to give it a go at home. I appreciated the thoughtful and well prepared resources Sarah gave us. Thank you!" - Megan
"Sourdough with Sarah was a delight!From feeling overwhelmed and giving up on the idea of ever making my own loaf of sourdough, to dancing with joy as i watch a beautiful perfect sourdough loaf get nice and golden in the homewood stove!The information was packaged in bite sizes with hands on practice in between, where we all got to experience each step of the whole process, which was cleverly condensed and prepared so that despite normally having waits in between, we were able to see it all play out in a short few hours!The process was beautifully organised with attention to detail that had us fawning, came away feeling so blessed and privileged!Sarah's glowing personality made all the information feel easy and palatable, it was so fun!Such a lovely time, great environment to learn with ease." -Melody

id: Immersive Yoga: We Are Nature-175 Vivian Street #Level 1 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: Immersive Yoga: We Are Nature
description:
Immersive Yoga: We Are Nature
A one-of-a-kind yoga experience designed to awaken the senses, stir reflection, and bring you into deeper connection — followed by a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert.
Take this moment to become grounded in your true nature through embodied movement. This practice is your invitation to appreciate and develop a deeper connection with the Earth — to slow down, to notice the changing landscapes and seasons around you, and to find them within you. It’s a chance to remember that we are part of this world, shaped by the same rhythms, held by the same ground.
We speak of “getting into nature” as something we have to do — yet Earth-based traditions have always seen the plant and all beings as interconnected and sacred, humans as one with the Earth itself.
This is more than a yoga class — it’s an immersive experience designed to bring you back into that sense of belonging.
As you move through gentle hatha yoga, you’ll be surrounded by breathtaking visuals of our earthly home, designed and projected by Andy from Hype Entertainment. The space will come alive with images of nature from sunset to sunrise — each scene offering a distinct atmosphere to reflect and move with. A curated soundscape and subtle aromatherapy will support your journey, drawing you deeper into the moment.
Let us weave the scared back in, to weave nature back into the centre of our everyday lives. Let us find our way back through nature, to our true nature and selves.
Event followed by a plant-based dinner and dessert, all included in your ticket!
Meet Your Host: Nicola
With over 20 years of teaching experience and a deep connection to yoga philosophy, Nicola’s gentle guidance will lead you on a journey of self-discovery. Her classes are a blend of warmth and wisdom, helping you explore both your body and your spirit. As a teacher, she embraces the essence of yoga in every aspect of her life, creating a space where you can experience not only physical movement but a true connection to your inner self.

id: InDuna - Go High - EP Release-167 Riddiford Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6021-Event Brite
name: InDuna - Go High - EP Release
description: Join Afro-Kiwi artist InDuna to celebrate the release of his brand new EP, ‘Go High’, live at Moon, Wellington on Saturday 2nd August.‘Go High’ is a gift from InDuna’s younger self to the artist he is today. It's an uplifting and reflective Afro-pop project inspired by his South African roots and journey of resilience. The EP is a reminder to keep dreaming boldly, no matter the obstacles.Doors open: 9:00 PMShow starts: 9:30 PMVenue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, WellingtonMoon is a wheelchair-accessible venue with both seated and standing options available.When the NFC ticket bundle is purchased, fans will get exclusive access to a limited edition NFC-enabled EP, featuring the full EP plus unreleased demos and future tracks, delivered directly to your device before they’re available anywhere else. InDuna merchandise will also be available on the night — don’t miss it.About InDuna:Self-taught artist and producer InDuna blends Afro-pop with the vibrant spirit of his South African heritage. He was recently honoured with the Young Global Achiever Award at the 2024 Prince’s Trust Awards in London and recognised at Buckingham Palace by King Charles III.His music has reached global ears, with his track ‘Dreams’, written for the documentary Ink and Gold: An Artist’s Journey to Olympic Glory, winning Best Original Song at the International Online Web Fest and climbing to #6 on the NZ Hot Singles Chart.

id: Inspired: Using Notion for Mindful Productivity-175 Vivian Street #Level 1 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: Inspired: Using Notion for Mindful Productivity
description:
Inspired: Using Notion for Mindful Productivity
What if your to-do list felt as nourishing as your breathwork practice?
This is the perfect 60-minute live workshop where Elebreath®️ meets mindful systems—a space to organize your life and business without slipping into hustle mode. We’ll blend somatic awareness with Notion, the all-in-one tool I use to manage my energy, organize my mind, and create with more ease.
Plus - there’s an amazing plant-based dinner & dessert after your event. All included in the ticket price!
This isn’t just about getting things done. It’s about doing it from a regulated, resourced place—so your nervous system feels held every step of the way.
Perfect for:
Soulful entrepreneurs, wellness professionals, creatives, and high-performers craving structure without burnout.
What You’ll Learn:
How your nervous system influences focus, clarity, and creative flow
How I integrate Elebreath®️ to map my energy before taking action
The exact Notion system I use to track tasks, brain dumps, and flow states
How to design a dashboard that moves with your body, not against it
You’ll Walk Away With:
A fully set-up Notion workspace that mirrors your calmest, clearest self
A Daily Flow Tracker + Brain Dump Inbox to release the mental clutter
Tools to show up consistently—even on low-energy days
Included in your ticket:
Lifetime access to the free resources like: guided breathwork, fatigue guide, and many more
My Notion templates & tracker bundle
Bonus PDF: Nervous-System Safe Productivity Rituals
An amazing plant-based dinner & dessert!
This is productivity with breath, intention, and soul.
Come as you are. Leave with clarity, calm, and a system that works with you.
Event followed by a plant-based dinner and dessert, all included in your ticket!

id: It's in the Ballot - Horizons RC–Manawatū-Rangitikei Constituency-In-studio-84 Aorangi Street Feilding, Manawatū-Whanganui Region 4702-Event Brite
name: It's in the Ballot - Horizons RC–Manawatū-Rangitikei Constituency-In-studio
description:
Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025

id: Karetao Wānanga-1 Fell Street Blenheim, Marlborough 7202-Event Brite
name: Karetao Wānanga
description:
We are honoured to welcome esteemed cultural practitioners James Webster, Hinemoa Jones, Rikki Solomon, Whetu Silver and Horomona Horo, who will share their immense mātauranga. Karetao are an integral part of Māori culture, despite limited documentation. During the revival of Taonga Pūoro, led by the late Dr. Hirini Melbourne, discussions highlighted the synergy between karetao and Taonga Pūoro. This collaboration enriches the performance and expression of Māori culture, weaving together sound, music, spirit, and storytelling.This wānanga includes a special performance on Friday evening, followed by weekend workshops focused on the creation of karetao.
This event is open to all whānau and community members — from tamariki to kaumātua.
Registrations are essential Cost: $50 per person (all ages)
PĀNUI
Registrations are accepted on a first come, first served basis. Unfortunately, we are unable to reserve or hold places in advance.
Refunds are not available. Your registration fee covers kai, wānanga content, and all materials provided for you to take home.
Accommodation is limited. If you require a noho (overnight stay), please contact us after confirming your registration for the wānanga to secure a spot.
This wānanga is a collaboration between Rangitāne o Wairau and Ngā Pakiaka Mōrehu o te Whenua, facilitated by Nell Kelly.

id: LHPC Antenatal Class 8 2025-12 Britannia Street Lower Hutt, Wellington 5012-Event Brite
name: LHPC Antenatal Class 8 2025
description:
Welcome to Lower Hutt Parents Centre, where parenting is everything.We are a group of parents helping new parents in our community. Lower Hutt Parents Centre ispart of a national voluntary-led, not-for-profit organisation who provide high quality ChildbirthEducation Classes (Antenatal Classes), Baby & You Classes and other Parent EducationClasses for Hutt Valley families.
CHILDBIRTH EDUCATION
Pregnancy and parenthood can be an exciting but daunting time! We are here to help. Our comprehensive Antenatal Classes lead by qualified Childbirth Educators will help you prepare for labour, birth and the early days with a newborn.
All Childbirth Education classes and Parent Education classes are held at St Augustine's Church Annexe (Britannia St, Petone). Each Childbirth Education course runs for six weeks, one evening per week, from 6.45pm - 9.15pm. From time to time a 'weekend intensive' course which runs for two full days is held on consecutive Saturdays.
Courses cost $220 (including booking fee)
The course covers:
• Nutrition and exercise during pregnancy
• Labour signs and stagesWe
• Pain relief options and interventions
• The birth process
• Breastfeeding and newborn care
• Transition to Parenthood and practical parenting
• A tour of Hutt Hospital maternity unit, either physical or virtual tour
We encourage you to enrol early to ensure you get a spot. We limit course numbers to 13 couples. In order to enrol, you must complete our registration form, and make payment for the course.

id: Lung Cancers in Palliative Care Workshop-331 Suffolk Road Nelson, Nelson 7011-Event Brite
name: Lung Cancers in Palliative Care Workshop
description:
In New Zealand, lung cancer causes more deaths than any other cancer, more than breast, prostate and melanoma combined. More than 1800 New Zealanders die from lung cancer each year. The reason that lung cancer has such a high mortality is that 74% of the patients present with advanced lung cancer on initial diagnosis (Cancer Research Trust , NZ).

Symptoms of lung cancer are varied and supporting people with advanced disease requires a holistic approach.

This workshop will look at
Understanding lung cancers and treatment options
Best practice symptom management
Understanding stigma and the social and family/ whānau implications

Presenters:
Toni Phair Community Clinical Nurse Specialist - Respiratory, Health New Zealand Te Whatu Ora

id: Motov8ing Boys - WELLINGTON-MacLaurin Lecture Theatres Wellington, Wellington 6012-Event Brite
name: Motov8ing Boys - WELLINGTON
description:
Do you worry about your sons attitude & behaviour?
Does he need help building courage, confidence & resilience?
Does he struggle to care about or see his potential?
Or are you just tired of repeating yourself over and over again only to get the same result, or even worse…no response at all?

If you answered yes & can relate to some or maybe even all of these then the Motov8ing Boys event is for you and it's time you met John McMahon.

Motov8ing Boys' is an event for Boys aged 11-17 and their parents; the goal is to help them to understand the power of a positive attitude, how to develop competnece & confidence, how to change destructive behaviour, how to identify personal potential & understand the importance of self-respect & respecting others, especially their parents.

One of the biggest deficits seen in young people today is a lack of social & emotional intelligence. This can lead to a whole range of problems with their personal development at home, at school & with friends both on & off line.
It can put unnecessary strain on relationships with siblings & sometimes unsustainable pressure on parents. Leading to everything from arguements, fights, anxiety, stress & depression through to significant family breakdown.
If you can relate to some or maybe even all of these then a Savage Angel event is for you.
Who is John McMahon from Motov8 aka The Rev?
John or Rev as he’s more commonly known is a youth specialist with over 30 years experience working with young people in schools, sporting clubs & families across Australia, NZ & the UK. Through Motov8ing Boys events, seminars & talks delivered in schools, Rev has helped inspire & influence thousands of young people to make smarter more informed decisions.
Boys will be boys" is often used to explain away & excuse why boys say & do silly things. As a coach/mentor and parent himself Rev would rather see this statement reflect a very different sentiment. Rev's aim is to inspire boys to choose to become history making, high achieving & uniquely productive young men. Men of substance, conviction & hopes to do something significant with their lives.
Why This Event - Why Motov8ing Boys?
As parents it is our role to guide and advise our sons but it's for that exact reason they often don't want to listen. Sometimes the same message communicated in a different way and by a different person, is all that's needed to start to turn things around.
This event gives parents the opportunity to expose their sons to real advice about life in terms of when the 'rubber hits the road'. Rev engages young males through the use of motorcycles & draws from his years of rider experience to help them to navigate the twists, turns & obstacles that inevitably come across on the ride of life. This event is about much more than motorcycles so even if that's not you or your sons thing there's still a lot of value to be taken away from it.
Rev's communication style is direct, confronting, hard hitting, relative & impactful on both the boys & their parents. He's as direct as they come but it's his raw vulnerability that earns him the right to say what needs to be said to both boys & parents.
What parents are saying about this event.

Brad & Morgan Thomas We went to the Gold Coast event feeling like we were on our own going through this parenting journey that is raising boys aged 12 and 15. We soon relaised that we were not alone in our pain and frustration. Rev had this way of cutting through games our boys play with us to manipulate things to serve themsleves. We walked away with some very confronting truths to face and embrace. Our boys walked away with some clear areas to improve on and some very strategic answers to excuses and objections they hide behind.

Hayley & Hunter Motov8 and Rev absolutely nailed it at the boys' event in Toowoomba! I went along with my 12-year-old son and his friend, and they were hooked from the get-go. Rev’s hard-hitting, raw truth style - mixed with powerful metaphors about life and motorbikes - really landed with them. They were so engaged they didn’t want to leave at the end and were both keen to chat with Rev afterwards. It’s not often you see two young boys hang off every word like that! Highly recommend for anyone raising boys who need strong, real, and relatable role models.

Claire Kelly A friend suggested it and I just had that immediate gut feeling, that we had to take our boys. So, with real effort we dragged 3 tired boys out, not really knowing what to expect. It was great! When we got in the car afterwards, one of them said: "Now that was surprisingly good, I actually really enjoyed it"; and the other 2 agreed. Win! Thank you Rev! We will def be interested in further workshops.

Seona Maybery My boy really didn't want to go to the workshop. I dragged him there with the attitude that it was going to be boring and so on. He couldn't believe that we would have to sit there for 2hrs but at the end of it he couldn't believe how quickly the time went. The comment was also "that wasn't as bad as I thought it was going to be". A win win situation for me and I really think he'll get something out of it. I know that I learnt some things myself. Thanks for teaching us some great strategies to help with the anger. So much to take away from this workshop.

Sarah Verheyen Thank you. Your words are empowering for our teenagers, as I saw in my own boys tonight. The reflection that I saw in them was astounding, and the little changes that started as soon as we walked in the door were proof of the way that you captured their attention. I myself found it very inspiring to hear the way that you have learned how to be a parent - truly inspiring for people like me who have to teach themselves as they weren't taught from an early age. You have given me some steps to further this journey. Your stories and anecdotes really engaged us all.Thanks Rev.

Aaron & Bree Clifford We've been questioning our parenting for some time, doubting ourselves and our values. We walked into this event and we knew very little about it but it was recomended to us by the wellbeing coordinator at our sons school. It was not like anything we had been to before and in a good way. Everything Rev said connected with us in a deep and real way. We walked out and it was like we were both on the same page again. We know what's best for our son and will parent through the pain to get him where he needs to go. Thanks Rev for having the balls to do what you do and say what you say.

Sonya Carter Thanks for your info tonight, I have to say you connected with my boys (both 12) really well in a short space of time (I didn't expect this!). I was impressed with your matter-of-fact approach to neuro-diversity (and so was my neurodiverse son, he's never heard ASD spoken about so bluntly and he liked it.) The three things you said parents want was spot on and our families best take away. Shining a light on our young men's mental health crisis is so important - thanks for your dedication. Take care

All reviews are posted up exactly as we reicive them, to read more CLICK HERE

Mum's please don’t just send your boys with their dad or your partner, where possible come as a family even if you’re separated. There are things that need to be said to your son & it’s much more impacting on them if you’re there next to them. There are just as import things that need to be said to you in front of them as well.
It's very comon for the same boys who whinge, bitch, protest & complain to their parents about having to come along to also be the first boys to come & show gratitude to Rev & their parents after the event is finished.
So, turn off their tech/screens/headsets & bring your boys out to a night of inspiration, motivation mixed with some TUFF love & good advice that could just change your & their lives forever.
What about the girls & their parents?
We also have a girls event called Savage Angels happening at the same location the following evening at the same time. To find out more CLICK HERE
A bit of a look inside a Motov8ing Bioys event.
Event feedback from parents & boys.

description:
You know the old saying “The boyfriend did it...”?

On an ill-fated night, love goes terribly wrong for Bella Wanderlust and Walter Bridges. Bella, the famous travel blogger, was found dead during a ghost tour led by the theatrical Percy Shadows. Now, since you're New Zealand's best detective, it’s up to you to dig out the truth and catch the murderer:

Was it Walter, the obsessed boyfriend?
Was it Percy, the ghost tour guide with a flair for the dramatic?
Or was it someone else hiding in the shadows?

Explore the streets, collect the clues, interrogate the suspects, decipher hidden messages, and piece together the evidence. Can you do it, Detective? Or will you end up the next victim?

Key Info:
🕵️‍♂️ - YOU are the detective and the phone is your loupe
🎮 - NO players limit per group
🏎️ - Start any day of the week, any hour
📍 - Explore 12 locations in your city, within a 2 km radius

id: Passchendaele: "Mighty few of the bearers are left"-1 Molesworth Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
name: Passchendaele: "Mighty few of the bearers are left"
description:
Passchendaele - a word that conjures up the horrors of all wars, especially for those now intimately connected with what was then a small and innocuous village in Flanders, the Flemish region of Belgium. In terms of casualties, the morning of 12 October 1917 was - and is - the worst and bleakest day in New Zealand’s history of warfare. 846 of our young men were killed on that morning alone and, by the end of the day, 2740 were dead, wounded or missing.
To commemorate those who fought and died, our Society Board invites you to join us and other guests as we remember the 1917 battle at Passchendaele.
The function will be hosted at Parliament Buildings by Cameron Brewer MP, Member for Upper Harbour and also a member of the Society.
Our guest speaker will be Dr Graham Howie, PhD, OStJ, a career paramedic and university lecturer in paramedicine. In his talk "Mighty few of the bearers are left" he will tell us about the work of stretcher-bearers at Passchendaele, those early paramedics who laboured under the most dreadful conditions to rescue the dead and wounded.

id: Peace over Panic - Rewiring the Anxious Mind-175 Vivian Street #Level 1 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: Peace over Panic - Rewiring the Anxious Mind
description:
Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars:
Peace over Panic - Rewiring the Anxious Mind
Transform your relationship with anxiety in just 60 minutes using the revolutionary FasterEFT technique that's helping thousands worldwide break free from the grip of panic and overwhelm.
In "Peace over Panic - Rewiring the Anxious Mind," you'll discover how your mind creates anxiety through unconscious patterns and learn a simple yet powerful tapping method to literally rewire your nervous system for calm and confidence.
Unlike traditional therapy that can take months or years, FasterEFT works at the subconscious level where anxiety is actually created, allowing you to experience immediate relief and lasting change. Whether you struggle with daily worry, panic attacks, or overwhelming stress, this workshop will give you practical tools to take control of your mental state and create the peaceful, confident life you deserve. Leave with a complete system you can use anywhere, anytime to transform anxiety into inner peace.
The seminar will be followed by a delicious plant-based dinner together, all included in your ticket!
Meet Your Host: Krishnaloka
Introducing Krishnaloka, who is driven to help others overcome their issues within their mind and pyschology. As a mind technician trained in eutaptics (Faster EFT), she employs the fastest and most powerful method to create lasting change by addressing the root causes of issues rather than just the symptoms. Her warm and caring nature makes every interaction with her both comforting and transformative.

id: Power Up: Navigating the Powerchair Landscape (Palmerston North)-748 Rangitikei Line Palmerston North, Manawatū-Whanganui Region 4475-Event Brite
name: Power Up: Navigating the Powerchair Landscape (Palmerston North)
venue: 748 Rangitikei Line Palmerston North, Manawatū-Whanganui Region 4475
description:
Powerchair Academy Palmerston North - Venue to be announced
_____________________________________________________________________________________________
Overview:
This training session will provide an in-depth look at the Quickie power wheelchair range, covering key features, clinical applications, and available adjustments to ensure future-proofing. Participants will explore alternative drive controls, including chin, head, and specialty switching, with hands-on opportunities. The session will also focus on outdoor mobility options, highlighting the Magic Mobility portfolio and clinical decision-making for product selection. Practical demonstrations, including the Q700-Up standing power wheelchair, will enhance learning and engagement.
About our Presenters:
Steve's Bio:
Product Consultant & Power Chair Specialist - Medifab
Steve’s career in the mobility industry began at 18, after forming a deep appreciation for wheelchair users from a young age. With over 30 years of experience, Steve first honed his skills as a technician, repairing and understanding the inner workings of power chairs. He later transitioned into sales and training, where he now helps therapists and advisors deliver tailored solutions.
Steve is driven by a passion to improve the lives of those with mobility challenges, sharing his expertise with technicians, end-users, and clinicians alike. His dedication extends beyond his work, having volunteered in Samoa to assist with wheelchair set-ups for those with limited resources.
Amy's Bio:
Clinical Director - Sunrise Medical
Based in Sydney, Australia, Amy develops and delivers national and international training programmes on Assistive Technology, focusing on enhancing inclusion, health, and well-being for individuals with physical disabilities. She also plays a key role in product improvement and development at Sunrise Medical Australia.
With a passion for innovation, Amy is dedicated to finding practical solutions that create meaningful change, even in challenging environments. She was instrumental in establishing Australia’s chapter of GoBabyGo, a charity promoting early mobility for young children.
Amy is an experienced speaker who has lectured extensively on seating and mobility, wound management, and spinal cord injury rehabilitation. She has also travelled to developing countries, sharing knowledge and learning from medical communities worldwide.

id: Savage Angels - WELLINGTON-MacLaurin Lecture Theatres Wellington, Wellington 6012-Event Brite
name: Savage Angels - WELLINGTON
description:
Do you worry about your daughters attitude & behaviour?
Does she strugle with a poor sense of self worth or fail to see her potential?
Does she lack courage, confidence & that spark she used to have?
Is she obsessed with her phone, social media or other tech?
Does she struggle to suuround herself with friends who are good for her?
Or are you just tired of repeating yourself over and over again only to get the same result, or even worse…no response at all?

If you answered yes & can relate to some or maybe even all of these then a Savage Angels event is for you.
Savage Angels is an event for girls aged 11-17 & their parents that's focused on Inspiring, Informing & Instructing them how to make smarter more informed decisions in life. We want to empower girls to hold core values that will allow them to stand strong in the face of social media & peer group influences. We know this event has the potential to make a huge difference in girls lives & their futures.
One of the biggest deficits seen in young people today is a lack of social & emotional intelligence. This can lead to a whole range of problems with their personal development at home, at school & with friends both on & off line.
It can put unnecessary strain on relationships with siblings & sometimes unsustainable pressure on parents. Leading to everything from arguements, fights, anxiety, stress & depression through to significant family breakdown.
The topics addressed at these events are all focused on personal development.
Things like self-esteem, confidence, friendships & relationships, social media & mainstream media influence, anxiety, stress, depression, suicide, mindset, apathy, hope, dreams & the hard work required to kick arse in life.
What parents are saying

Ryan & Torrey Hansel - Rev hit the nail right on the head with everything that was said at the Ipswich event we went to. We came for our girls but both of us parents walked away with just as much if not more than them. What was said about the value girls place on people they don't like or care about & what they say will stay with our younger daughter for life, she was so impressed with that simple concept that was taught. Thank you R, T, M15 & H12

Ele Hosie - Savage angel was such an awesome experience the story’s where so real and it was incredibly inspirational and interesting to hear so many peoples stories I feel savage angel really shows you what people are going through and gives you a different perspective on things

Kirsten Webster - Thanks for a very powerful evening Rev. My 12year old daughter took a lot from the night and I have definitely noticed more peace, respect and contribution from her since! I also took a lot from it, I am absolutely stepping up my consistency with consequences. I highly recommend this to parents of girls who just need a little support with communication.

Lisa Short - Great evening, presentation was down to earth, related well to young audience. I recommend, certainly got nothing to lose so why not go along! it starts conversations.....

Sharon Baptist - The session was very open and honest and encouraging. A lot of the core values we had already discussed at home but hearing from Lana and Jo really impressed our girl!! An amazing night and I highly suggest going

Melanie Nicholls - Well worth taking my daughter to this last night. Some very sad stories helped her to put her own life into perspective and she walked away being able to analise the values of true friendship. I’m grateful that she could hear this talk at a young age. Thankyou.

Belinda Marshall - Thank you so much to everyone involved in Savage Angel; tonight was fantastic! The speakers were so inspiring, all with different stories to tell. My 13yo daughter loved it and we will certainly be attending another event in the future.

Taesha - Hi I’m Taesha and I’m using my mums phone I came to the first event tonight and it definitely has made me feel much braver and inspired me to push myself to be the best I can be. I’m 10 years old and got a lot out of the event. Thanks for the savage angel cap and I will wear it proudly.

Deborah Jean Scott - Wow what an awesome experience for both my girls 12 & 16. We all had tears in our eyes at different parts, even Dad. I can't recommend it more highly and would love to become involved with it, in some way. It will only keep going from strength to strength. Thank you all so much for sharing with us xxxx

All reviews are posted up exactly as we reicive them, to read more CLICK HERE
Our ultimate goal is to influence millions of girls across the planet to blaze their own trail & to do it with a great sense of purpose. To do it like the Savage Angels we know they can become.
Warning: These events are not for the politically correct because young people & parents don't think politically correctly when going through a tough time. We fully intend to say things that we know will challenge & upset both young people & parents so don't come along expecting it to be all marshmallows, unicorns & fairy dust because it will be anything but that. The message will be strong to both girls & their parents because that's how we get the results we do.

Please don't book in with a large group of friends, this is not another girls night out it's much more important than that. This is also not just a mother & daughter event, where possible try to come as a family even if you're separated & it's appropriate to do so.
So turn of the tech, screens & headsets they can do without TikTok, Insta & YouTube for 2hrs. Ignore the potential complaints & objections they wont resent you for bringing them, well not for very long.lol
We hope you can make it along to this very significant event.
The Savage Angel Team

What about the boys & their parents?
We also have a boys event called Motov8ing Boys happening at the same location the night before at the same time. To find out more CLICK HERE

id: THE HOUSE OF HEALING: BREATHWORK EVENT-15 Johnston Street #Level 2 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
name: THE HOUSE OF HEALING: BREATHWORK EVENT
description:
Welcome to THE HOUSE OF HEALING: BREATHWORK EVENT!
Come join us at AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing for a transformative experience through the power of breathwork.
Are you ready to meet yourself on a whole new level?

Breathwork is not just breathing... it Is a direct path to transformation.

A way to release stored emotions, clear subconscious blocks, and reconnect with the fullest, most powerful version of yourself.

In this guided breathwork journey, you will go beyond the mind and into the intelligence of your body, unlocking the healing potential that already exists within you.

WHAT IS BREATHWORK?
Breathwork is a powerful practice that uses conscious, intentional breathing to access deep states of awareness, healing, and release. It allows you to move beyond the analytical mind and tap into the subconscious, where unprocessed emotions, limiting beliefs, and past experiences are stored.

Through specific breathing techniques, you can:
• Release emotional tension and stored trauma
•Gain clarity and insight on areas of your life that feel stuck
•Regulate your nervous system and reduce stress
•Expand your sense of self-awareness and personal power
•Connect to a deeper sense of inner peace, presence, and possibility

This is not just relaxation.

This is an active, embodied experience designed to shift energy, elevate consciousness, and help you break through whatever is holding you back.

WHO IS THIS FOR?

This session is open to everyone, provided you do not have any contra-indications (listed below).

Whether you are brand new to breathwork or have experienced its depth before, you are welcome here.
If you have never done breathwork, this is a safe and supportive space to explore its power for the first time.
If you've done breathwork before, this is an opportunity to go deeper, refine your practice, and receive exactly what you need in this moment.

WHAT TO EXPECT
• An introduction to your nervous system & the way it stores stress & trauma, stopping you from living your best life (and how breathwork can help you to fix this)
•A guided one hour breathwork journey with Jacqui Sive, holding space for your personal experience
• A safe, grounded, and warm environment for deep transformation & integration afterwards

IMPORTANT NOTES
Breathwork can bring up deep emotions and physical sensations. While it is a safe practice for most people, it is not recommended if you are pregnant, have a history of epilepsy or severe heart conditions, or experience certain psychiatric conditions. If you are unsure, please consult your doctor before attending.

This is an opportunity to experience what is possible when you allow yourself to breathe fully, feel deeply, and trust the process
Spots are limited - please feel free to reach out via Instagram (@thehouseofhealing or @lightleadershipwithjacqui) if you have any questions.

id: Te Manu Tāiko - Māori Student Experience Day Pukeahu 2025-Wallace Street Wellington, Wellington 6021-Event Brite
name: Te Manu Tāiko - Māori Student Experience Day Pukeahu 2025
description:
Nau mai ki a Te Manu Tāiko – A Wānanga for Future Māori Leaders
Join us for a series of inspiring workshops led by some of Massey University’s leading creatives, thinkers, and doers. Through hands-on activities and thought-provoking kōrero, you’ll explore themes of cultural identity, leadership, and what it means to thrive in education as Māori.
This wānanga is designed for senior Māori secondary students who are thinking about university and want a real taste of what that journey could look like. You’ll get to connect with other like-minded tauira from across the motu, meet current Māori students and staff, and experience the unique support available to help you succeed at Massey.
Come explore the spaces, stories, and opportunities waiting for you — and start building the future you want, grounded in who you are.
Register: 9:00am
Mihi whakatau starts at 9:30am
We will also host student panels and tours across the campus after our workshops
Day finishes at 2:30pm

Friday 1st August 2025
Please select 1 workshop from the following:
Creative Expression through Indigenous Knowledge. Explore Indigenous knowledge through art in this hands-on workshop grounded in Mātauranga Toi Māori. You’ll create a small artwork inspired by one of three themes: Mātauranga Toi Māori, Te Rau Karamu marae, or Puke Ariki — each offering a unique connection to culture, place, and story.
Sounds of the Land: Taonga Pūoro & Technology in Harmony. Join Associate Join Associate Professor Horomona Horo (Ngāpuhi, Ngāti Porou, Taranaki) for an inspiring journey into the world of taonga pūoro — the traditional musical instruments of Aotearoa — and their deep connection to whenua.
Pikorua in 3D: Design, Create, Connect. In this workshop, you’ll bring together mātauranga Māori, tech, and sustainability to create something meaningful. You’ll start by designing your own infinity swirl — the Pikorua — using beginner-friendly 3D software. Then, using a pre-printed version made from recycled plastic, you’ll learn how to remove support structures, sand it down, and tie on the aho (cord).
Shoot & Go: No-Edit Film Challenge! Keen to try filmmaking but not sure where to start? In this hands-on wānanga, you'll get a quick bootcamp on using a Canon cinema camera, then head out in a small rōpū to plan and shoot your own short film — with a twist. Every cut has to be made in-camera. No retakes. No editing. Just solid mahi and sharp storytelling.
Lead, Support, and Stay Prepared. Join Hinemoa Katene for an interactive introduction to emergency response through Coordinated Incident Management System (CIMS) training. This hands-on workshop empowers rangatahi Māori to build confidence, leadership, and practical skills to support whānau and iwi in times of natural disaster. Learn how to work together to strengthen community preparedness and be ready when it matters most.
Unleash your imagination through storytelling.Storytelling is a powerful way to express and share ideas and explore new worlds. Whether it’s through writing, speaking, or creating, every story matters. Join award-winning writer Whiti Hereaka in a practical workshop to hone your storytelling.
Find Your Voice, Shape Your Future.Communication is at the heart of connection – whether you're telling a story, sharing an idea, or working with others. In this engaging workshop, you will explore the many ways communication can lead to exciting paths in media, tech, leadership, the arts, and more. Build confidence, spark creativity, and discover where your voice can take you with award winning playwright Elspeth Tilley.
Discover the Art in Science. You'll learn how to reveal the hidden beauty of rocks through a polarised microscope. By examining thin sections of rock, students will uncover stunning, colourful mineral patterns – nature’s own artwork revealed through science. Perfect for curious minds and budding geologists!
Create a Character. Whether you’re into games, movies or animation, this is your chance to bring characters, creatures and environments to life. We’ll lean into Māori wood carving and create your own detailed 3D sculpture. Work step-by-step, shaping in ZBrush and adding realistic textures and colour in Substance Painter. No prior tech knowledge necessary.
Photography. Exploring Cyanotypes and Alternative Photographic Processes Join a senior Māori Photography student and a Photography lecturer in a hands-on workshop to explore the creative world of cyanotypes, one of the earliest forms of photography.
Spatial Design. Explore Spatial Design and its role in shaping the spaces we engage every day. Guided by tikanga and processes of kōrerorero, hui, and wānanga, we’ll examine how design can elevate our stories of people and place.
Industrial Design. Explore the types of processes used by Industrial Designers and see the huge range of possibilities in the 3D Workshop.
Understanding Us: A Dive into Psychology.
Explore how and why we think, feel, and act the way we do through the lens of psychology. This workshop introduces Indigenous Māori psychologies and clinical psychology — two powerful areas that help us understand both ourselves and others. Learn about Massey’s Centre for Indigenous Psychologies and discover how psychology can support wellbeing and create real change.


We’ll provide lunch, please bring your own drink bottle. Wear something comfortable so you can move easily and get a bit messy.
Any questions please e-mail Barbara Scott at B.Scott2@massey.ac.nz

We’re looking forward to hosting you.
Ngā manaakitanga

Discover the ancient wisdom of food, energy, and balance in this insightful session with Dr. Jinfeng — plus enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, included with your ticket.
Many people believe they’re eating healthily, yet still experience fatigue, inflammation, and discomfort. Why is that?
From a Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) perspective, health isn’t just about what you eat — it’s also about when you eat, the energetic nature of the food, and how well it suits your unique body type. In this workshop, you’ll explore food as medicine and gain insight into how to eat in a way that restores vitality, supports digestion, and balances your energy naturally.
What you’ll learn– The energetic qualities of different foods– How to identify which foods suit your constitution best– The ideal times to eat during the day and why timing matters– How TCM views food as fuel for both physical health and life force
Whether you're curious about Eastern approaches to wellness or looking for practical tools to support your health, this workshop will offer a fresh and meaningful perspective on your relationship with food.
Event followed by a plant-based dinner and dessert, all included in your ticket!
Meet Your Host: Jinfeng
As a scholarly well-being practitioner with a long history of family heritage (great grandfather and father), Dr. Jinfeng has been practicing Taoist Qigong and Buddhism Great Awakening Zen Meditation to sharpen her own sense and boost her own physical vitality.

id: Whakataua: An adornment workshop with Neke Moa-45 Laings Road Lower Hutt, Wellington 5010-Event Brite
name: Whakataua: An adornment workshop with Neke Moa
description:
Bring in any treasures that you’ve foraged – shells, sticks, stones – and create a wearable artwork out of them. Some shells and fibre will be supplied. There are a limited number of spaces available for this workshop, so make sure you register to guarantee your place.
Neke Moa (Ngāti Kahungunu ki Ahuriri, Kai Tahu, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Tūwharetoa) is an adornment and object artist, predominantly working with Pounamu (NZ jade). In 2000 she gained a Diploma of Design and Art at Te Waananga-o-Raukawa and then furthered her studies at Whitireia NZ, completing a Bachelor of Applied Arts in 2007. Moa has exhibited widely throughout Aotearoa and internationally. Over the last 4 years Moa has taught shell craft in Fiji and Tonga and continues to teach and learn as part of her art practice.

description:
Yin Yoga & Sound Healing

Slow yoga, soothing sounds, and a nourishing plant-based meal—a grounding evening from start to finish.
Take a pause from the rush and settle into an evening of deep rest and reconnection. This special session combines the stillness of yin yoga with the soothing power of sound healing—an immersive experience to calm the body and quiet the mind.
Yin yoga is a slow, meditative practice where poses are held for several minutes, allowing the body to open gently and the nervous system to reset. It’s a chance to soften, breathe, and listen inward.
As you rest in each pose, you’ll be surrounded by the gentle sounds of healing frequencies. Sound healing works on a vibrational level—helping to release tension, restore balance, and bring a sense of inner peace.
Guided by Nicola’s thoughtful approach to yin and Nizaad’s calming presence with sound, this evening is a space to simply be—to feel, to unwind, and to receive.
To close the night, we’ll share a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert—included in your ticket.
All levels welcome.

This calming evening will centre around the deeply restorative practice of Yoga Nidra—a guided meditation designed to bring your body into a state of deep rest while your awareness gently drifts between waking and dreaming. id: Your Parenting ACT, July 2025-21 Hania St Mt Victoria Wellington, 6011-Event Brite
name: Your Parenting ACT, July 2025
description:
Parenting can be both a joy and very hard work.
But things get in the way of us being the parents we want to be - including our own thoughts and feelings. These can be about ourselves, about our children, about our parenting, or about what others think about our parenting.
Your Parenting ACT is a 6 week course for parents of school aged children where you can develop a strong foundation for your parenting. It helps you understand your child, develop your self, nurture your relationship with your child and parent in line with your values. It uses principles from ACT — Acceptance and Commitment Training — to help you make room for all your thoughts and feelings, so you can respond more calmly and flexibly as a parent.
ACT uses acceptance, mindfulness and behavioural strategies to help people pursue what matters most to them, including being the parent they want to be.
We know that people wonder whether groups are for them! But we find that discovering ACT with and from people who are having similar experiences such as parenting, is very effective and fun. A recent attendee said:
"I can read all the books, but there's nothing like meeting and hearing from other parents."


The course is held over six consecutive Tuesday evenings from 7:00pm to 9:00pm.
We understand that sometimes things get in the way of plans, and occasionally people can't make a night of the course. But it is essential that you attend the first night of the course in order to take part in the remaining sessions. The course includes invitations to share and experiential exercises that work best when we are able to get to know one another and develop trust in the group.

This course needs a minimum number of parents to go ahead. So if you've decided to come, please sign up! It's very helpful to know that we have enough people to proceed.


Giselle Bahr is a clinical psychologist working in Wellington who continues to parent two adult children. She works primarily with young people and their families in private practice. Before that she spent 15 years working in Wellington's public health system and teaching in a university clinical training programme.
Tania Stanton works as a clinical psychologist at the Maternal Mental Health Service. She has previously worked in Infant, Child, Adolescent and Family Services where she co-developed and facilitated therapy groups for young people and their parents using ACT. She is enthusiastic about the help that ACT can offer to enhance people’s lives.
